pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 121, 648, 146]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 185, 189]]<|/det|>
PHYSICS Paper 1 Multiple Choice

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[847, 172, 908, 187]]<|/det|>
9702/13

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[764, 195, 907, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025 1 hour 15 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 248, 509, 266]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 279, 438, 296]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 306, 540, 323]]<|/det|>
Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 231, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 601, 372]]<|/det|>
- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. - For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Choose the one you consider correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 682, 399]]<|/det|>
and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet. - Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 413, 280, 430]]<|/det|>
- Write in soft pencil. - Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 442, 521, 459]]<|/det|>
spaces provided unless this has been done for you. - Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 474, 369, 491]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes. - You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 536, 222, 549]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION - The total mark for this paper is 40 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 564, 446, 579]]<|/det|>
- Each correct answer will score one mark. - Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 126, 89]]<|/det|>
Data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 102, 271, 116]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g=9.81 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 135, 306, 150]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c=3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 168, 238, 181]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(\quad e=1.60 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 200, 265, 214]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \mathrm{u}=1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 232, 265, 247]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}}=1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 265, 256, 279]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}}=9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 297, 239, 311]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}}=6.02 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 330, 239, 344]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R=8.31 \mathrm{~JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 361, 247, 376]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k=1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~JK}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 394, 261, 408]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 427, 286, 442]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\varepsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~Fm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 447, 631, 478]]<|/det|>
\[
(\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}=8.99 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~mF}^{-1})
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 495, 217, 508]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h=6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 526, 311, 543]]<|/det|>
Stefan-Boltzmann constant \(\sigma=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2} \mathrm{~K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 587, 168, 601]]<|/det|>
Formulae

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 614, 322, 629]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 632, 565, 649]]<|/det|>
\[
v^{2}=u^{2}+2 a s
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 665, 250, 680]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p=\rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 696, 154, 711]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F=\rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 726, 339, 743]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_{0}=\frac{f_{s} v}{v \pm v_{s}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 767, 209, 780]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I=A n v q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 797, 228, 812]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R=R_{1}+R_{2}+ \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 823, 239, 840]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R}=\frac{1}{R_{1}}+\frac{1}{R_{2}}+\ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 407, 91]]<|/det|>
1 What represents a vector quantity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 258, 118]]<|/det|>
A 1 N upwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 269, 143]]<|/det|>
B 2 kg decrease

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 154, 238, 169]]<|/det|>
C 3 K cooler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 222, 196]]<|/det|>
D 4 s later

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 761, 241]]<|/det|>
2 What is a reasonable estimate of the current in an electric kettle that is in use?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 192, 270]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 8 \mu \mathrm{~A}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 254, 363, 269]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 8 \mathrm{~mA}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 254, 515, 269]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 8 \mathrm{~A}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 254, 692, 270]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 8 \mathrm{kA}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 298, 601, 314]]<|/det|>
3 Which statement about errors in measurements is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 326, 708, 344]]<|/det|>
A An accurate set of measurements always has a small random error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 711, 369]]<|/det|>
B A precise set of measurements always has a small systematic error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 808, 394]]<|/det|>
C A random error can be reduced by taking an average of several measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 898, 421]]<|/det|>
D A systematic error creates a random set of measurements spread out about the true value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 449, 918, 466]]<|/det|>
4 A sample of material has cross-sectional area \(A\) and length \(L\). The temperatures at the two sides of the sample are \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\). Thermal energy \(Q\) is transferred through the sample in time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 493, 377, 510]]<|/det|>
These quantities are related by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 523, 591, 562]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{Q}{t}=\frac{k \times A \times\left(T_{1}-T_{2}\right)}{L}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 300, 590]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 605, 391, 621]]<|/det|>
What are the SI base units of \(k\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 632, 247, 649]]<|/det|>
A \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-3}{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 632, 413, 649]]<|/det|>
B \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-3} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 632, 581, 649]]<|/det|>
C \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 632, 747, 649]]<|/det|>
D \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 848, 91]]<|/det|>
5 The graph shows the variation of velocity with time \(t\) of an object moving in a straight line.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 102, 796, 288]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 500, 319]]<|/det|>
At \(t=0\), the displacement of the object is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 526, 350]]<|/det|>
What is the displacement of the object at \(t=20 \mathrm{~s}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 193, 376]]<|/det|>
A -3 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 361, 361, 376]]<|/det|>
B 21 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 361, 529, 376]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 24 \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 361, 695, 376]]<|/det|>
D 27 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 408, 918, 424]]<|/det|>
6 A science museum designs an experiment to show the fall of a feather in a vertical glass vacuum tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 451, 621, 466]]<|/det|>
The time of fall from rest in the vacuum is to be close to 0.5 s .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 482, 391, 497]]<|/det|>
Which length of tube is required?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 509, 201, 524]]<|/det|>
A 1.2 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 509, 366, 524]]<|/det|>
B 2.5 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 509, 535, 524]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 4.9 \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 509, 700, 524]]<|/det|>
D 9.8 m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 730, 91]]<|/det|>
7 Two coins are projected from a horizontal table at the same initial speed \(u\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 377, 120]]<|/det|>
Coin \(X\) is projected horizontally.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 642, 151]]<|/det|>
Coin \(Y\) is projected upwards at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 166, 714, 287]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 302, 559, 317]]<|/det|>
Both coins hit the horizontal ground without bouncing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 548, 349]]<|/det|>
Assume the air resistance on each coin is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 363, 590, 378]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the motion of the coins is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 540, 407]]<|/det|>
A Both coins hit the ground with the same speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 416, 515, 430]]<|/det|>
B Both coins travel the same vertical distance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 443, 457, 459]]<|/det|>
C Coin Y hits the ground before coin X .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 468, 501, 483]]<|/det|>
D Coin Y has a smaller vertical acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 513, 700, 529]]<|/det|>
8 Two spheres are released from rest at equal heights above the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 542, 424, 557]]<|/det|>
Both spheres reach terminal velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 574, 567, 589]]<|/det|>
One sphere has a larger density than the other sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 603, 402, 618]]<|/det|>
Both spheres have equal volumes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 634, 697, 649]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct while both spheres are at terminal velocity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 500, 677]]<|/det|>
A The drag forces on the spheres are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 687, 532, 703]]<|/det|>
B The resultant forces on the spheres are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 714, 477, 729]]<|/det|>
C The velocities of the spheres are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 739, 465, 754]]<|/det|>
D The weights of the spheres are equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 382, 89]]<|/det|>
9 Which statement defines force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 918, 118]]<|/det|>
A When a force acts on a body that is free to move, the force is the product of the mass of the body and its acceleration.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 142, 918, 159]]<|/det|>
B When a force acts on a body that is free to move, the force is the rate of change of momentum of the body.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 918, 200]]<|/det|>
C When a force acts on a body that is free to move, the force is the work done by the force divided by the distance moved by the body.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 224, 918, 242]]<|/det|>
D When a force acts on a lever and causes a moment, the force is the moment divided by the perpendicular distance of the force from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 285, 539, 302]]<|/det|>
10 Four forces, all in the same plane, act on an object.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[370, 314, 631, 490]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 496, 520]]<|/det|>
What could describe the motion of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 531, 294, 547]]<|/det|>
A It is accelerating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 388, 575]]<|/det|>
B It is moving in a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 583, 443, 602]]<|/det|>
C It is moving with decreasing speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 608, 479, 626]]<|/det|>
D It is moving with increasing momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
11 A nucleus collides with a stationary nucleus in a vacuum. The diagrams show the paths of the nuclei before and after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 494, 136]]<|/det|>
No other particles are involved in the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 380, 166]]<|/det|>
Which diagram is not possible?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 179, 330, 192]]<|/det|>
A

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 203, 460, 286]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[657, 179, 678, 192]]<|/det|>
B

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 213, 774, 248]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 312, 330, 326]]<|/det|>
C

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 344, 438, 388]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[657, 312, 678, 326]]<|/det|>
D

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[562, 336, 770, 408]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 433, 595, 449]]<|/det|>
12 A non-uniform bar PQ has length 50 cm and weight 200 N .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 460, 747, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 918, 585]]<|/det|>
A block of weight 400 N is attached to the top of the bar at its centre. The bar rests on horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 614, 918, 630]]<|/det|>
A vertical force of 360 N is now exerted upwards on the bar at end Q and is just sufficient to lift end Q from the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 661, 664, 676]]<|/det|>
What is the distance from the centre of gravity of the bar to end P ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 222, 703]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0.050 \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 688, 377, 703]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.10 \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 688, 545, 703]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 0.25 \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 688, 711, 703]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 0.40 \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 734, 385, 749]]<|/det|>
13 What is the definition of density?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 762, 358, 777]]<|/det|>
A mass of one cubic metre

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 788, 335, 803]]<|/det|>
B mass of a unit volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 813, 333, 828]]<|/det|>
C mass per cubic metre

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 839, 333, 853]]<|/det|>
D mass per unit volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 410, 91]]<|/det|>
14 A block is in equilibrium on a slope.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 101, 598, 160]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 689, 189]]<|/det|>
Which vector triangle represents the three forces acting on the block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[257, 201, 279, 216]]<|/det|>
A

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 228, 294, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 201, 435, 216]]<|/det|>
B

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[399, 228, 450, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[565, 201, 587, 216]]<|/det|>
C

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[532, 224, 602, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[715, 201, 750, 216]]<|/det|>
D

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[704, 226, 755, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 343, 515, 361]]<|/det|>
15 A measuring cylinder contains \(80 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of a liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 375, 617, 392]]<|/det|>
The pressure due to the liquid at the \(60 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) mark is 1200 Pa .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 744, 421]]<|/det|>
What is the pressure due to the liquid at the base of the measuring cylinder?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 222, 448]]<|/det|>
A 1200 Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 433, 390, 448]]<|/det|>
B 1600 Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 433, 556, 448]]<|/det|>
C 3600 Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 433, 722, 448]]<|/det|>
D 4800 Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 478, 879, 495]]<|/det|>
16 Four identical uniform blocks are spread on a table. Each block has mass \(m\) and thickness \(h\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[194, 505, 808, 599]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 611, 382, 626]]<|/det|>
The acceleration of free fall is \(g\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 761, 657]]<|/det|>
How much work is done on the blocks in stacking them on top of one another?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 669, 203, 684]]<|/det|>
A 3 m g h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 669, 369, 684]]<|/det|>
B 6 m g h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 669, 537, 684]]<|/det|>
C 8 m g h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 669, 712, 684]]<|/det|>
D 10 m g h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 714, 650, 730]]<|/det|>
17 An electric motor uses 1.7 kW of power when operating normally.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 743, 405, 760]]<|/det|>
The efficiency of the motor is \(53 \%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 774, 493, 790]]<|/det|>
What is the useful output power of the motor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 802, 234, 816]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0.032 \mathrm{kW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 802, 388, 816]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.90 \mathrm{kW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 802, 545, 816]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 3.2 \mathrm{kW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 802, 707, 816]]<|/det|>
D 90 kW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 609, 91]]<|/det|> 18 A ball is released from rest and falls vertically to the ground. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 876, 122]]<|/det|> The kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of the ball varies as the height \(h\) of the ball above the ground changes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 338, 150]]<|/det|> Air resistance is negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 496, 181]]<|/det|> Which graph shows the variation of \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) with \(h\) ? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[234, 191, 438, 351]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[258, 372, 355, 388]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 392, 438, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[66, 564, 711, 583]]<|/det|> 19 An object travelling with a speed of \(10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) has kinetic energy of 1500 J . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 593, 509, 611]]<|/det|> The speed of the object is increased to \(40 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 624, 487, 641]]<|/det|> What is the new kinetic energy of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 652, 211, 667]]<|/det|> A 4500 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 652, 376, 667]]<|/det|> B 6000 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 652, 554, 667]]<|/det|> C 24000 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 652, 745, 667]]<|/det|> D 1350000 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 697, 611, 714]]<|/det|> 20 What are the units of stress, strain and the Young modulus? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 726, 518, 870]]<|/det|>
stress
strain
Young
modulus
A
newton
metre
pascal
B
newton
no unit
newton
C
pascal
metre
newton
D
pascal
no unit
pascal

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 554, 91]]<|/det|>
21 The force-extension graph for a metal wire is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 102, 661, 255]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 606, 288]]<|/det|>
Which quantity is represented by the area under the graph?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 393, 314]]<|/det|>
A power transferred to the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 324, 421, 341]]<|/det|>
B temperature increase in the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 421, 366]]<|/det|>
C time taken for the wire to extend

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 377, 338, 392]]<|/det|>
D work done on the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 421, 918, 438]]<|/det|>
22 A wire of length \(L_{0}\) is attached at one end to a fixed point. A tensile force is applied to the other end so that the wire extends and has a new length \(L_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 466, 363, 481]]<|/det|>
What is the strain of the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 492, 184, 529]]<|/det|>
A \(\left(\frac{L_{1}}{L_{0}}\right)-1\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 502, 377, 518]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad L_{1}-L_{0}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 490, 565, 529]]<|/det|>
C \(\left(\frac{L_{1}}{L_{0}}\right)+1\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[618, 502, 711, 516]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad L_{1}+L_{0}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 678, 91]]<|/det|>
23 A wire of length \(L\) is stretched to determine its limit of proportionality.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 811, 120]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the variation of the extension \(x\) with the force \(F\) applied to the wire.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 133, 686, 292]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 611, 323]]<|/det|>
The limit of proportionality is shown by point P on the graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 337, 918, 352]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated with another wire of length \(2 L\) but of the same material and same diameter as the first wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 741, 398]]<|/det|>
Which point on the graph shows the limit of proportionality for the new wire?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 409, 688, 570]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
24 The graph shows the variation with distance along the wave of the displacement of water particles at a particular instant in time for a transverse water wave.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 119, 827, 304]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 664, 338]]<|/det|>
P, Q and R show the positions of three water particles in the wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 609, 367]]<|/det|>
Which particle has the greatest speed at the instant shown?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 358, 393]]<|/det|>
A all have the same speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 236, 421]]<|/det|>
B particle P

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 430, 236, 446]]<|/det|>
C particle Q

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 236, 471]]<|/det|>
D particle R

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 503, 634, 518]]<|/det|>
25 Which phenomenon is only associated with transverse waves?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 530, 236, 545]]<|/det|>
A diffraction

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 556, 256, 571]]<|/det|>
B interference

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 581, 253, 598]]<|/det|>
C polarisation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 607, 234, 623]]<|/det|>
D reflection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 443, 91]]<|/det|>
26 A wave is displayed on an oscilloscope.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 102, 642, 267]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 281, 363, 298]]<|/det|>
The oscilloscope settings are:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 311, 328]]<|/det|>
time-base: \(300 \mu \mathrm{~sdiv}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 341, 271, 360]]<|/det|>
\(y\)-gain: \(40 \mu \mathrm{~Vdiv}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 372, 410, 389]]<|/det|>
What is the frequency of the wave?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 400, 214, 415]]<|/det|>
A 130 Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 400, 380, 415]]<|/det|>
B 950 Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 400, 557, 415]]<|/det|>
C 1100 Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 400, 725, 415]]<|/det|>
D 7100 Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 445, 780, 462]]<|/det|>
27 An electromagnetic wave travelling in free space is not visible to the human eye.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 479, 491]]<|/det|>
What is a possible wavelength of the wave?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 269, 520]]<|/det|>
A \(4.5 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~km}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 531, 256, 547]]<|/det|>
B \(6.2 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 264, 573]]<|/det|>
C \(5.4 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~cm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 585, 269, 602]]<|/det|>
D \(4.2 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~mm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
28 Electromagnetic waves of equal wavelengths are emitted from two sources, \(X\) and \(Y\). The waves are emitted from \(X\) and \(Y\) with a phase difference of \(180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
A detector moves along a path that is parallel to the line XY and detects a pattern of intensity maxima and minima.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 780, 181]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the arrangement of the sources and the path of the detector.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 191, 716, 304]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 318, 852, 336]]<|/det|>
An intensity maximum is detected at point \(Z\). Length XZ is 70 cm and length YZ is 110 cm .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 349, 490, 366]]<|/det|>
What is a possible wavelength of the waves?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 376, 206, 391]]<|/det|>
A 10 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 376, 372, 391]]<|/det|>
B 16 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 376, 540, 391]]<|/det|>
C 20 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 376, 706, 391]]<|/det|>
D 40 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 421, 427, 438]]<|/det|>
29 Two waves of the same type overlap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 451, 515, 469]]<|/det|>
When does the principle of superposition apply?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 480, 214, 497]]<|/det|>
A always

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 505, 540, 522]]<|/det|>
B only when the waves have the same amplitude

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 531, 556, 548]]<|/det|>
C only when the waves travel in opposite directions

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 558, 543, 575]]<|/det|>
D only when the waves have the same frequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 515, 91]]<|/det|>
30 A ripple tank contains water at a constant depth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 892, 120]]<|/det|>
A water wave of constant frequency travels towards a gap in a barrier placed in the ripple tank.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 131, 609, 286]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 298, 327, 313]]<|/det|>
The gap is made smaller.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 328, 645, 344]]<|/det|>
Which diagram represents the wave before and after the barrier?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[315, 357, 337, 372]]<|/det|>
A

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 384, 788, 511]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[315, 554, 337, 569]]<|/det|>
C

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[218, 581, 787, 709]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 736, 918, 753]]<|/det|>
31 Light of a single frequency from two coherent sources interferes to produce a pattern of bright and dark fringes on a screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 782, 537, 799]]<|/det|>
Which change results in a larger fringe separation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 810, 648, 825]]<|/det|>
A increasing the distance between the sources and the screen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 835, 554, 851]]<|/det|>
B increasing the distance between the two sources

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 860, 449, 877]]<|/det|>
C increasing the frequency of the light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 886, 435, 903]]<|/det|>
D increasing the intensity of the light

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 719, 91]]<|/det|>
32 The current \(I\) in a metallic conductor of cross-sectional area \(A\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[461, 105, 537, 120]]<|/det|>
\[
I=A n e
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 876, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(e\) is the elementary charge and \(v\) is the mean drift velocity of the conduction electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 168, 539, 182]]<|/det|>
What is represented by the letter \(n\) in the equation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 410, 210]]<|/det|>
A density of conduction electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 220, 521, 235]]<|/det|>
B number of conduction electrons per unit time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 246, 545, 261]]<|/det|>
C number of conduction electrons per unit volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 271, 413, 285]]<|/det|>
D volume of conduction electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 316, 518, 333]]<|/det|>
33 What cannot be the charge on a charge carrier?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 269, 360]]<|/det|>
A \(-4.8 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 371, 269, 386]]<|/det|>
B \(-3.2 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 398, 269, 413]]<|/det|>
C \(-2.4 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 425, 269, 440]]<|/det|>
D \(+3.2 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 470, 698, 485]]<|/det|>
34 A steel wire with a length of 2.20 m is connected to a battery as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[372, 500, 626, 657]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 671, 780, 688]]<|/det|>
The reading on the voltmeter is 1.50 V and the reading on the ammeter is 4.90 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 702, 451, 719]]<|/det|>
The resistivity of steel is \(6.90 \times 10^{-7} \Omega \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 731, 435, 748]]<|/det|>
What is the diameter of the steel wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 760, 264, 776]]<|/det|>
A \(1.76 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 760, 430, 776]]<|/det|>
B \(3.52 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 759, 648, 778]]<|/det|>
C \(1.26 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[661, 760, 764, 776]]<|/det|>
D \(2.51 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
35 Two resistors of resistance \(R\) and two resistors of resistance \(3 R\) are connected to a cell of e.m.f. 8.0 V as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 463, 136]]<|/det|>
The cell has negligible internal resistance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 148, 637, 308]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 428, 337]]<|/det|>
What is the reading on the voltmeter?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 198, 364]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0.0 \mathrm{~V}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 351, 363, 364]]<|/det|>
B \(2.0 \mathrm{~V}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 351, 529, 364]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 4.0 \mathrm{~V}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 351, 697, 364]]<|/det|>
D \(6.0 \mathrm{~V}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 396, 918, 411]]<|/det|>
36 A battery has an e.m.f. \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\). The battery delivers a current \(I\) to a variable resistor and the p.d. across its terminals is \(V\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[360, 435, 640, 595]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 614, 543, 629]]<|/det|>
The variable resistor is adjusted so that \(I\) increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 311, 658]]<|/det|>
Why does \(V\) decrease?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 671, 352, 686]]<|/det|>
A The e.m.f. \(E\) decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 696, 443, 711]]<|/det|>
B The internal resistance \(r\) increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 722, 382, 737]]<|/det|>
C The p.d. across \(r\) increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 747, 554, 762]]<|/det|>
D The resistance of the variable resistor increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 37 An electrical device of fixed resistance \(20 \Omega\) is connected in series with a variable resistor and a battery of e.m.f. 16 V and negligible internal resistance. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 119, 621, 270]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 287, 556, 302]]<|/det|> The power dissipated in the electrical device is 4.0 W . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 496, 331]]<|/det|> What is the resistance of the variable resistor? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 346, 195, 360]]<|/det|> A \(16 \Omega\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 346, 361, 360]]<|/det|> B \(36 \Omega\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 346, 529, 361]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 44 \Omega\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 346, 695, 361]]<|/det|> D \(64 \Omega\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 392, 466, 409]]<|/det|> 38 A nucleus decays by emitting a \(\beta^{+}\) particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 421, 567, 436]]<|/det|> Which particle must also be emitted from the nucleus? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 449, 253, 464]]<|/det|> A antineutrino <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 474, 239, 491]]<|/det|> B \(\beta^{-}\) particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 501, 234, 518]]<|/det|> C \(\alpha\)-particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 528, 225, 542]]<|/det|> D neutrino <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 572, 725, 588]]<|/det|> 39 What are the charges on an antidown quark and an antistrange quark? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 523, 816]]<|/det|>
antidown quark
antistrange quark
A
\(\quad+\frac{1}{3} e\)
\(\quad+\frac{1}{3} e\)
B
\(\quad+\frac{1}{3} e\)
\(-\frac{1}{3} e\)
C
\(-\frac{1}{3} e\)
\(+\frac{1}{3} e\)
D
\(-\frac{1}{3} e\)
\(-\frac{1}{3} e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
40 The nucleus of a radioactive isotope of an element emits an \(\alpha\)-particle. The daughter nucleus then emits a \(\beta^{-}\) particle and then the daughter nucleus of that reaction emits another \(\beta^{-}\) particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 603, 138]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the final nuclide that is formed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 526, 166]]<|/det|>
A It is a different isotope of the original element.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 175, 650, 191]]<|/det|>
B It is a nuclide of a different element of higher proton number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 201, 708, 216]]<|/det|>
C It is a nuclide of the same element but with different proton number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 226, 443, 243]]<|/det|>
D It is identical to the original nuclide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[436, 74, 562, 89]]<|/det|>
